pros: Flexibility and great team spirit. The college has really invested in its staff and understands that to be innovative, you must fund positions that fuel creativity and “outside the box” problem solving.

review_title: It's an OK place to work
pros: The benefits are really good. Great co-workers. If you like working with young people, a very energizing environment. The Administration really does try to create a positive culture - with varing results. They are trying, though. Baby steps.
cons: The quailty of management across the organization varies and your experience as an employee will mirror that. Some departments are happy and engaged, others are not.

pros: Everyone here was friendly, especially my boss. It was a very chill working environment without people looking over your shoulder or checking in on you constantly, we were trusted to get our work done and not over supervised.

job_title: Associate Director, Career Collaborative in Burlington, VT
pros: Champlain College puts students at the heart of everything it does.
cons:
We are the best-kept "secret" among schools in the U.S. Champlain is known in Vermont and in New England; however, the College is not as well known outside of New England.

Due to Covid, the College recently closed its Office of International Education, but remains committed to providing study-abroad experiences for students once the pandemic has been controlled and travel is once again safe.

pros: Always growing and adapting and innovating
cons: Needs a little more stability in staff and faculty

pros:

Lacks diversity even though there are strong commitments to diversity in the mission statements.
Moved to a coaching model and does no annual review/evaluation. Sounds great but can be frustrating and not provide the correct opportunities for growth.

review_title: Leadership has not been strong for the past 7 years
pros: Great place to work, friendly people who care a lot about the students
cons: Poor leadership - Deans, Associate Deans, Provost, President for past 7 years.

pros: A fun time with good people.
cons: work can be slow but that also means more time to work on other stuff.

review_title: The best Filmmaking Program in New England

job_title: 3D Modeler and Texture Artist in Burlington, VT
pros: - Friendly leads and awesome team
cons: - Remote work is difficult for game development

review_title: High Potential, Little Self Reflection and Organizational Responsiveness
pros: Great variety of classes, expert instructors in some areas that come from realms of real-world experience especially business and game design, and generally decent and functional facilities with good staffing on physical spaces front. A small enough school to network within your realm easily, and approach direct supervisors without needing a set reason or appointment. Faculty can often be found in their offices, and people generally seem to like being there. Attempts by staff and admin to really enrich student life with events, speakers and support of student clubs, bring it far past its days as a accounting school for locals.
cons: So many issues it's hard to make them seem connected. Organizationally challenged to the point of dysfunctional, not clear emphasis on any of the things they call "core values" or stated objectives and goals; lack of followthrough and accountability of both leadership and instructors seems par; student failure/mediocrity/flakiness is seemingly ok as long as they keep paying tuition; serious concerns about ability to keep up high-esteem that exists given that acceptance and retention rates aren't wonderful. Some facilities and initiatives seem funded but inaccessible to the college community. From an academic perspective, it is no longer the place for adult learners. Despite strong classes, the culture is not as tied to real-world, work- and life-experience as it boasts to be.

review_title: Champlain College - A great place to work if your expectations aren't too high.
pros: Champlain College manages to hire some wonderful, qualified, and hard-working people - these people are one of the best reasons to work at the College.  The benefits are great, in my experience, and easily accessible.
cons: There is virtually no opportunity for career development, at least among staff.  It's essentially a flat organization, and many of the long-tenured employees aren't planning on moving out of their positions, so there's a fairly large level of stasis in some of these long-tenured employees.  This means there's a great deal of pushback at times in terms of change, and in a very real way the business world has passed these people by. Frankly, many of them are simply unequipped to survive in a place other than where they are.  A "status quo" mentality is rampant amongst this select group of staff, and it's reflected in a high staff turnover rate.  The pay scales for the staff positions lag the market, too, which probably contributes to turnover.

pros: Understanding management that wants you to succeed
cons: Must be a student to work most jobs

pros: As an adjunct there is a lot of flexbility in how to run the course - maybe too much ? There is not much guidance or concern for what will be taught during the semester. This is great if you are on the ball and self motivated but could be a problem if deadwood professors slip in.
cons: Some students are unmotivated - but that is the case everywhere. As an adjunct it would be nice to be given more preparatory material for a course. So far each course I've basically been given a textbook and a blank slate. I think pay of $3k per semester per course is way to low - it should be double that.

review_title: Any workstudy position at Champlain College can be enjoyable, relevant to your degree, and flexible with your schedule.
pros: It is a great working environment because it is typically with people you know and doing things that pertain to your degree. The best part of a workstudy position is how flexible your hours are so that you can work around your class schedules.
cons: The pay rates are challenging to live by. Being a full-time student doesn't leave much time to work, which is why workstudy positions are great, but the pay isn't enough to buy groceries, gas, personal items, phone bills, etc.

review_title: My experience as online adjunct is overwhelmingly positive.
pros:
I am treated with respect, and my supervisors have always involved me in the process. 

Expectations are clear.

The biggest pro I can give is that Champlain College trusts faculty to complete the work they were hired to perform.

Adjunct faculty are not just shoved to the side, as they are at many institutions. Even as an online adjunct faculty member, I am provided responsibility for courses and given plenty of professional development opportunities.
cons: Some would argue that adjuncts should be paid the same per course as full-time faculty.

review_title: Great place, could be better with clearer vision/direction
pros: nice employees, great opportunities to grow through new projects, health care coverage, overall benefits package, past track record of institutional success.
cons: Lack of clear vision at the top; challenging budget reality for private higher education has reduced benefits; employee experience differs greatly based on department leader.

review_title: Enthusiastic, energized team of educators striving to be the finest small, professionally and globally focused college
pros: Positive working climate, striving to provide the very best post secondary education possible.  The small community often feels like a big family.
cons: Has big dreams and justly celebrates success but, still acts small time in customer service areas. The small community often feels like a big family.  Increased responsibly and advancement are slow.

review_title: Champlain College is a teaching-focused educational institution with huge potential.
pros: Champlain is a career focused, high quality, experimental institution of higher learning, affording faculty high academic and classroom freedom.  The focus is on career relevant student education. Faculty regularly work across program and division boundaries leading to huge potential for innovation.
cons: Low Levels of Faculty Support, High Expectations for Faculty Involvement, High Cost of Living, Poor Support Infrastructure and Lack of Sufficient Resources to meet Lofty Goals, Administration is Reactive, not Proactive, Administration Does Not Value Faculty Input.

pros: Great people at a passionate and progressive institution. Incredibly generous full-time benefits package (significant PTO, tuition remission, 403(b), and much more). And it's in an amazing location. Never got bored working here--every day brought a new challenge or opportunity.
cons: Senior Management can often be vague with sharing decisions, departments sometimes stay in their lanes too much (which makes collaboration hard at times), and it's a small organization--so expect to wear a lot of hats.

pros: Teaching is great. Labs are well staffed with support from students and the equipment gets the job done.
cons: Recently found out Champlain Adjuncts are the lowest paid in the area. Being a graduate of Champlain College and paying their tuition fees, I was a little shocked by this.

review_title: Overall a great place with some inefficiencies
job_title: Student Employee Level II in Burlington, VT
pros: The people at Champlain are great, many of the facilities are top notch and the community as a whole is supportive
cons: There's a lot of inefficiency and lack of communication between departments. Sometimes it's unclear who does what. Some of the systems and technology are also integrated poorly.

review_title: Two positions: Library Aide and Student Tutor
job_title: Library Aide/Student Tutor in Burlington, VT
pros: These have been great opportunities to both build my resume and to earn a little extra cash while in school here.
cons: Sometimes it can present a challenge when the payment systems change and you are unknowingly left with outstanding OnBoarding to do.

pros: I loved working at Champlain College.  There were a lot of great people there, with a lot of great ideas. People genuinely wanted to help each other out. Professional advancement was a big part of conversations.
cons: Leadership could have heard the voices of employees and specific segments of the student population more.
